column6: Mixed public and church schools in three Slovak regions

column8: Learn with M.E. software used to personalize basic math instruction
column11: No standardized cognitive tests used; task accuracy logged in digital workbook
column12: Likert-scale questionnaire on user motivation and experience
column13: Student workbook logs, task performance database, teacher interviews
column14: Descriptive statistics, frequency analysis, SPSS, user performance logs
column15: Structured interviews, thematic content grouping, SWOT analysis
column16: Convergent mixed-methods with control group comparison
column17: Increased motivation and improved perceived understanding of math; personalized learning paths noted
column18: No explicit effect size reported; software accuracy in error detection: 92%

column20: Improved calculation skills and understanding of operations, supported by adaptive task generation
column21: Software helped identify and correct errors, aiding problem-solving practice
column22: Trophies, gamification, and error feedback boosted student interest (82.3% enjoyed math more)
column23: No data on anxiety, but students found software “motivating” and “fun”
column24: Desktop app with personalized feedback, error recognition, trophy system, multilingual support
column25: Perceived as effective by students and teachers; high engagement reported
column26: Teacher training on interpretation of task logs; instructional support features like solution steps
column27: Noted SES disparities in access/use preferences (e.g., Slovak vs. Hungarian vs. English language)
column28: Suggests personalized digital tools with real-time feedback can support inclusive and adaptive math education.

column1: Lida Asencios-Trujillo, Lucia Asencios-Trujillo, Carlos La-Rosa-Longobardi, Djamila Gallegos-Espinoza
column4: Not explicitly stated for the main study, but survey involved 22 respondents (implied from percentages in Figs 13-21)
column5: 9 to 11 years old; Survey respondents aged 5-9 mostly
column6: Children with difficulties in math/reading; Initial evaluation identified students with phonological/verbal memory issues for reading
column7: Agile Scrum methodology used for development; Evaluation involved surveys and standardized tests comparing software users to traditional methods
column8: Educational software with interactive games (Memorama, Sum game) and didactic exercises for basic math and reading comprehension
column11: Standardized tests (details not specified), Entrance tests (phonological knowledge, verbal memory for reading)
column17: Notable improvement in performance for software users vs. traditional methods; Increased motivation and class participation observed
column18: Not explicitly stated by authors, potential limitations mentioned in discussion include narrow age range initially targeted (6-8 planned, 9-11 studied) and lack of implemented inclusive learning methods
column19: Software improved basic math skills (e.g., addition via Sum Game); Enhanced understanding through diverse resources and interactive exercises
column20: Software designed to enhance problem-solving through interactive methods
column21: Software aims to inspire students and increase motivation/participation through interactive games and didactic exercises; Survey showed positive reception of games (Memorama rated good/excellent by ~91%)
column22: Software designed to address disinterest and distraction; Aims to make learning enjoyable
column23: Interactive educational software (web system) developed using Visual Studio Code, HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, SQL Server; Includes login, course access, Memorama (memory game), Sum game (addition)
column24: Software users showed notable improvement compared to traditional methods; Positive user feedback on usability (login rated good/excellent by ~91%)
column25: Software development involved educators; Principles included differentiated instruction and continuous assessment/feedback; Teachers can assign personalized exercises
column26: Survey data suggests mothers and siblings are primary helpers at home; Significant connectivity issues hindered remote learning programs like "Aprendo en Casa" during pandemic; Computer most used device (54.5%), followed by cell phone (27.3%)
column27: Project currently targets 9-11 years (study) but aims to expand; Inclusive learning methods not yet implemented; More mini-games planned

column1: Luca Cerniglia, Silvia Cimino, Massimo Ammaniti
column6: Children exceeding AAP screen time recommendations, no major developmental disorders
column8: Daily use of smartphones and tablets for educational apps and short videos, assessed at age 4
column9: No control group (all participants exceeded AAP limits)
column10: Home (T0), school settings for teacher assessments (T1, T2)
column11: Teacher Report Form (TRF) Mathematics and Literacy T-scores
column12: Dysregulation Profile from TRF (Anxious/Depressed, Attention Problems, Aggression)
column13: StimQ-PIDA for parental scaffolding, SCL-90/R for maternal risk
column14: Pearson correlation, MANOVA, Structural Equation Modeling (SEM)
column15: Content-based group comparisons, no thematic coding reported
column17: Higher screen time at age 4 predicted dysregulation at ages 6 and 8; lower academic performance at age 8 only, mediated by dysregulation
column18: Standardized regression weights β = -0.34 to -0.57 for key paths; effect size η² = 0.34 (math at T2)
column19: No control group; maternal scaffolding not tracked over time; no direct cognitive testing
column20: Mathematics grades at age 8 were significantly lower in non-scaffolded group (M = 21.3 vs 28.1)
column21: No direct mention of computational thinking or structured problem-solving intervention
column22: Children with higher parental scaffolding showed significantly better engagement and emotional regulation at age 6
column23: Dysregulation at age 8 predicted by earlier screen time; indirectly linked to anxiety, withdrawal, attention issues
column24: Tablets and smartphones used for passive video watching and educational apps
column25: Tools less effective long-term without parental scaffolding; academic decline observed by age 8
column26: Scaffolding measured with PIDA subscale; higher PIDA scores correlated with better academic outcomes
column27: Lower-income families and mothers with less education showed higher screen time exposure in children
column28: Findings support that dysregulation mediates academic decline due to early excessive screen time; parental engagement delays but does not prevent cognitive/emotional impact

column1: Chen, I.H., Gamble, J.H., Lee, Z.H., Fu, Q.L.

column1: Carmen David, Cristina Costescu, Adrian Roșan

column22: No observed improvement in engagement for either group

column22: Gamification increased engagement and frequency of tool use

column6: Primary school children in rural Assam; low access to technology
column7: Longitudinal panel with cross-sectional comparison; quasi-experimental
column8: No specific digital intervention; natural experiment of school closure during COVID
column9: Pre-pandemic comparison (grades/schools), no explicit control group
column10: In-class and at-home testing across multiple years

column18: Mathematics: –0.30σ; Language: –0.39σ compared to pre-pandemic cohorts

column20: Math learning declined 0.30σ—equivalent to 9 months of education lost; especially in low-SES students
column21: Problem-solving not directly measured, but regular math practice and tech access reduced learning loss
column22: Psychological wellbeing significantly improved across both personal and school domains
column23: Not measured; no anxiety scale used; only positive CAPSAW wellbeing change reported
column24: Smartphone, internet, WhatsApp, radio/TV, educational materials, parental coaching
column25: Tech and tuition mitigated loss: phone calls (+0.096σ math), internet (+0.122σ), tuition (+0.102σ language)
column26: Weekly learning, teacher interaction, tech use showed positive gains; teacher contact critical
column27: Children from low-education households and with younger siblings suffered greater losses
column28: Comprehensive five-year dataset; highlights regressive impact of crisis and resilience of wellbeing.

column20: English learning loss of −0.275 SD in Grade 5; math −0.052 SD in G5, −0.163 SD in G8, reading −0.085 SD in G8
column21: Moderate improvements for foreign students; quick start and guidance mitigated loss in some cases
column22: Greater loss linked to limited use of digital tools; engagement inferred via use of materials
column23: Conceptual discussion of emotional impact, no direct measurement

column25: Apps/tools were variably effective; better outcomes when used consistently with guidance and early start

column1: Hima, L. R., Nusantara, T., Hidayanto, E., Rahardjo, S., & Murniasih, T. R.

column1: Kajiwara, Y., Matsuoka, A., & Shinbo, F.
column6: Broad age range from elementary to elderly
column8: Machine Learning Role-Playing Game (ML-RPG), interactive and theoretical approach
column14: Descriptive statistics, percentage of correct answers
column17: ML-RPG enabled understanding of ML processes: perception (K1–3), data representation/reasoning (K4–6), and model learning/evaluation (K7+); positive shift in AI impressions.
column19: Complex ML processes may reduce interest; elderly dropout rate; limited AI limitation education
column20: Elementary students understood basic ML perception; middle/high school students grasped loss function minimization using graphs.
column21: Decision tree role-playing enhanced understanding of ML processes for K4–12 students.

column24: ML-RPG (interactive game with graphs and decision trees)
column25: ML-RPG effective for teaching supervised learning and improving AI acceptance (80% positive impression shift).
column26: Instructional design using decision trees and graphs critical for age-appropriate ML education.
column27: Elderly participants showed higher dropout due to complexity; low self-efficacy linked to disinterest (Table 11).
column28: Workshops demonstrating AI use cases recommended to reduce anxiety.
